summary.para: Protean.Tools.Conversion is designed to covert from one data source to another (e.g. Excel to Xml)

example.para: Exmaple usage to convert an Excel file to XML
example.code: Dim c As New Conversion(Conversion.Type.Excel, Conversion.Type.Xml, "c:\text.xls")
If c.State = Status.Succeeded Then Response.Write c.Output.OuterXml Else Response.Write c.Message

member.name: T:Protean.Tools.GnuPG.GnuPGWrapper
member.summary:
This class is a wrapper class for GNU Privacy Guard (GnuPG). It execute the command line program (gpg.exe) in an different process, redirects standard input (stdin), standard output (stdout) and standard error (stderr) streams, and monitors the streams to fetch the results of the encryption/signing operation.
Please note that you must have INSTALLED GnuPG AND generated/imported the appropriate keys before using this class.
GnuPG stands for GNU Privacy Guard and is GNU's tool for secure communication and data storage. It can be used to encrypt data and to create digital signatures. It includes an advanced key management facility and is compliant with the proposed OpenPGP Internet standard as described in RFC 2440. As such, GnuPG is a complete and free replacement for PGP.
This class has been developed and tested with GnuPG v1.2.0 (MingW32)
For more about GNU, please refer to http://www.gnu.org
For more about GnuPG, please refer to http://www.gnupg.org
For more about OpenPGP (RFC 2440), please refer to http://www.gnupg.org/rfc2440.html

Command property: set the type of command to execute (sign, encrypt...)

member.summary:
Boolean flag: if true, GnuPG creates ASCII armored output (text output).
Defaults to true (ASCII ouput).

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.GnuPG.GnuPGWrapper.recipient
member.summary:
Recipient email address - mandatory when command is Encrypt or SignAndEncrypt
GnuPG uses this parameter to find the associated public key. You must have imported this public key in your keyring before.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.GnuPG.GnuPGWrapper.originator
member.summary:
Originator email address - recommended when command is Sign or SignAndEncrypt
GnuPG uses this parameter to find the associated secret key. You must have imported this secret key in your keyring before. Otherwise, GnuPG uses the first secret key in your keyring to sign messages. This property is mapped to the "--default-key" option.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.GnuPG.GnuPGWrapper.yes
member.summary:
Boolean flag; if true, GnuPG assumes "yes" on most questions.
Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.GnuPG.GnuPGWrapper.batch
member.summary:
Boolean flag; if true, GnuPG uses batch mode (Never ask, do not allow interactive commands).
Defaults to true.

member.name: T:Protean.Tools.Encryption.Hash
member.summary: Hash functions are fundamental to modern cryptography. These functions map binary strings of an arbitrary length to small binary strings of a fixed length, known as hash values. A cryptographic hash function has the property that it is computationally infeasible to find two distinct inputs that hash to the same value. Hash functions are commonly used with digital signatures and for EncData integrity.

member.summary: Asymmetric encryption uses a pair of keys to encrypt and decrypt. There is a "public" key which is used to encrypt. Decrypting, on the other hand, requires both the "public" key and an additional "private" key. The advantage is that people can send you encrypted messages without being able to decrypt them.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterRelationship.TwitterRelationshipElement.NotificationsEnabled
member.summary: Whether the in-context user receives device notifications regarding status updates of other user
member.returns: An boolean that indicates if the in-context user receives device notifications regarding status updates of the other user.
member.remarks:
Due to its private nature, the Twitter API only populates this property in the context of the source user and only if the source user is authenticated.
The NotificationsEnabled property of the TwitterRelationshipElement object in the context of the target user will always be Null, as will the NotificationsEnabled property of the TwitterRelationshipElement object in the context of the source user if the source user is unauthenticated.

member.name: M:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterRelationship.TwitterRelationshipElement.#ctor(System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Creates a new TwitterRelationshipElement object.
member.param: An XmlNode from the Twitter API response representing a relationship element.
member.remarks: As exposed by the Twitter API, a relationship between two users is made up of two elements. Each element shows Following and FollowedBy relationship in the context of one particular user. Both elements will contain the same information, but are provided by the Twitter API for "clarity".

member.summary: A class that defines a search.

Most search tasks can be accomplished by just calling the Search method of the SearchMethods object and passing it the text you are searching for. If you're looking for more control over your search results, you'll want to pass a TwitterSearchParameters object.
You define a search by creating an instance of this class, and adding parameters to it. At the least, you must define the SearchTerm. See the example below.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterTrend.TrendName
member.summary: The name of the trend, as displayed on the Twitter website

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterTrend.TrendText
member.summary: Either the URL of a Twitter search, or the terms of a Twitter search, depending on which Trends method was called.
member.remarks:
The Twitter API returns different information for different trends requests.
If you called Trends(), this is a URL to a Twitter search.
If you called TrendsCurrent(), TrendsDaily() or TrendsWeekly(), this is a Twitter search string.

member.name: P:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterTrend.AsOf
member.summary: The effective date of the Twitter trend.
member.remarks: If you called TrendsDaily() or TrendsWeekly(), you will usually see multiple trends in the list with different dates. For more information, see http://apiwiki.twitter.com/Twitter-Search-API-Method:-trends-daily or http://apiwiki.twitter.com/Twitter-Search-API-Method:-trends-weekly

member.summary: Creates a TwitterTrend object.
member.param: The name of the trend.
The text of the trend.

member.name: M:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterAPI.GetAuthenticationLink(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns a URL that will allow users to authenticate your application with Twitter.

The Consumer Key Secret assigned to your application by Twitter.
The Url where users are taken after successful authentication.
member.returns: A String containing the URL where the user can authenticate your application.
member.remarks: This method should only be used when you need to specify a callback url that is different from the one in your Twitter application registration. For example, you would probably pass a CallbackUrl of "http://localhost" to do local testing.

member.name: M:Protean.Tools.Integration.Twitter.TwitterVB2.TwitterAPI.ValidatePIN(System.String)

member.param: The PIN number given to your user when they authorized your application.
member.returns: If the PIN is correct, True, otherwise, False.
member.remarks: GetAuthorizationLink() must be called before this method, and both methods must be executed against the same instance of the TwitterOAuth object. See the Twitter OAuth Tutorial at the TwitterVB web site for details on the OAuth process.

member.name: T:Protean.Tools.XmlNamespaceStripper
member.summary: Some of the Twitter XML payloads contain namespaces. They are implemented poorly and inconsistently. Rather than try to deal with their sloppy namespacing, this class simply removes all of the namespaces and gives us a clean XML document.
